subject: polity
title: Union Territories of India - Administration, Powers & Special Provisions
description: Comprehensive coverage of all 8 Union Territories with their administrative structures, special provisions, key bills, amendments, and exam-relevant constitutional provisions

rows.type_status:
**NCT - Special Status**
**Art 239AA** (69th Amendment 1991)
Part capital, part UT
**Partial statehood**
rows.administration:
**Lieutenant Governor** (Art 239AA)
Appointed by President
Acts on **Council of Ministers' advice** (except land, police, public order)
**Dual control**: LG + CM
rows.legislature:
**Legislative Assembly** (70 members)
Directly elected (5-year term)
**Chief Minister** heads Council of Ministers
**Cannot legislate** on: Police, Public order, Land (reserved for Parliament)
rows.special_provisions:
**Art 239AA**: Special status for Delhi
**Art 239AB**: Council of Ministers for Delhi
**7th Schedule**: Entry 1, 2, 18 (Union List) reserved for Centre
**Excluded subjects**: Police, Public Order, Land
CM responsible to Assembly, but LG has overriding powers
rows.key_bills_acts:
**Government of NCT of Delhi (Amendment) Act 2021**:
• LG not bound by CM's advice
• LG has final say on all matters
• "Government" means LG, not CM
• Services controlled by LG, not CM

**Landmark Cases**:
• **Government of NCT of Delhi v. Union of India (2018)**: SC held LG must act on CM's advice (except excluded subjects)
• **Government of NCT of Delhi v. Union of India (2023)**: SC held Services under Centre, not Delhi govt

**69th Amendment 1991**: Created NCT status for Delhi
rows.exam_points:
**Most asked UT in exams**
• **Art 239AA** - Most important
• Delhi = **Partial statehood** (neither full State nor full UT)
• **3 subjects** reserved for Parliament: Police, Public Order, Land
• 2021 Act strengthened LG's powers over CM
• 2023 SC verdict: Services (IAS/bureaucracy) under Centre
• **Capital of India** + Union Territory
• Only UT with **70-member Assembly** (highest)

rows.type_status:
**UT with Legislature**
**Art 239A** (14th Amendment 1962)
Former French colony
**Partial statehood**
rows.administration:
**Lieutenant Governor** (Art 239A)
Appointed by President
Acts on **CM's advice** (except law & order, police)
Less powerful than Delhi LG
rows.legislature:
**Legislative Assembly** (33 members: 30 elected + 3 nominated)
Directly elected (5-year term)
**Chief Minister** heads govt
**Cannot legislate** on: Public order, Police
**Nominated members**: 3 by Centre (usually MPs)
rows.special_provisions:
**Art 239A**: Puducherry can have Legislature & Council of Ministers
**7th Schedule**: Most State List subjects available
**More autonomy** than Delhi in practice
CM has more control than Delhi CM
LG generally acts on CM's advice (convention)
rows.key_bills_acts:
**14th Amendment 1962**: Granted Legislature & CM to Puducherry

**Puducherry became UT**: 1962 (after French left in 1954)

**Renaming**: Pondicherry → Puducherry (2006)

**No major controversies** like Delhi (CM-LG relations smooth)

**Key feature**: More like a State in functioning despite being UT
rows.exam_points:
• **Art 239A** - Special provision for Puducherry
• **Only UT** with **nominated members** in Assembly (3 members)
• Former **French colony** (unlike others - British)
• **33-member Assembly** (30 elected + 3 nominated)
• More autonomy than Delhi in practice
• Comprises 4 regions: Puducherry, Karaikal, Mahe, Yanam
• **Less controversial** than Delhi (CM-LG relations better)
• Similar to Delhi but with less conflict

rows.type_status:
**UT with Legislature**
Former State (downgraded 2019)
**Art 370 abrogated** (2019)
Highly controversial
rows.administration:
**Lieutenant Governor** (Art 239)
Appointed by President
**Extensive powers** over all subjects
More powerful than State Governors
**Security matters**: Direct LG control
rows.legislature:
**Legislative Assembly** (114 members: 90 elected + 24 seats reserved for PoK)
Directly elected (5-year term - elections held Oct 2024)
**Chief Minister** heads govt
**LG has overriding powers** on all matters
First Assembly after reorganization formed in 2024
rows.special_provisions:
**Art 370 ABROGATED** (Aug 5, 2019)
**Art 371** type provisions NOT extended
**President's Rule** since June 2018
**J&K Reorganisation Act 2019**: Divided J&K into 2 UTs (J&K + Ladakh)
**No special provisions** currently
All Constitution articles apply (except special state provisions)
rows.key_bills_acts:
**J&K Reorganisation Act 2019** (Most important):
• Bifurcated J&K into 2 UTs: J&K + Ladakh
• **Abrogated Art 370** (special status)
• Abrogated Art 35A (permanent residency)
• J&K = UT with Legislature
• Ladakh = UT without Legislature
• Effective: Oct 31, 2019

**Landmark Cases**:
• **In re: Article 370 of the Constitution (2023)**: SC upheld abrogation of Art 370 (5-judge bench, pending final verdict as of 2024)

**Key Provision**: Statehood promised to be restored later
rows.exam_points:
**Most controversial & most asked in exams**
• **Only State downgraded to UT** in Indian history
• **Art 370 abrogated** (Aug 5, 2019) - VERY IMPORTANT
• **Art 35A abrogated** - Permanent residency provisions removed
• Bifurcated into **2 UTs**: J&K (with Legislature) + Ladakh (without Legislature)
• **J&K Reorganisation Act 2019** - Most important Act
• **114-member Assembly** (90 elected, 24 reserved for PoK)
• **Statehood restoration** promised by Centre
• First UT Assembly elections held: **Oct 2024**
• LG has **more powers** than in States

rows.type_status:
**UT without Legislature**
Created from J&K (2019)
**No Assembly**
Direct Central control
rows.administration:
**Lieutenant Governor** (Art 239)
Appointed by President
**Direct rule** - No CM, No Assembly
**All powers** with LG
Reports to Union Home Ministry
rows.legislature:
**No Legislature**
**No Assembly, No CM**
Direct Central administration through LG
**Autonomous Hill Councils**:
• Leh Autonomous Hill Development Council (LAHDC Leh)
• Kargil Autonomous Hill Development Council (LAHDC Kargil)
Councils have limited local governance powers
rows.special_provisions:
**No Legislature** as per J&K Reorganisation Act 2019
**No special constitutional provisions** (Art 370/35A removed)
**Autonomous Hill Councils** continue (created 1995 & 2003)
All laws made by **Parliament only**
**6th Schedule NOT applied** (despite demand)
rows.key_bills_acts:
**J&K Reorganisation Act 2019**:
• Created Ladakh as separate UT without Legislature
• Separated from J&K on Oct 31, 2019
• Comprises: Leh & Kargil districts

**Demands**:
• **Statehood** or Union Territory with Legislature
• **6th Schedule** protection (tribal rights)
• **Separate Lok Sabha seats** (currently part of Ladakh constituency - 1 seat)

**Key Issue**: Local opposition to UT status without Legislature
rows.exam_points:
• **Newest UT** (created Oct 31, 2019)
• **Only UT in India without any Legislature** (among inhabited UTs)
• Created from bifurcation of J&K
• Comprises **2 districts**: Leh (Buddhist majority) + Kargil (Muslim majority)
• **1 Lok Sabha seat** (Ladakh constituency)
• **Autonomous Hill Councils** provide limited local governance
• **Demanding**: 6th Schedule, Statehood, Separate LS seats
• **Strategic location**: China (Aksai Chin) & Pakistan (PoK) borders
• **International boundary disputes** in region

rows.type_status:
**UT without Legislature**
**Joint capital**: Punjab & Haryana
Planned city (Le Corbusier)
**Shared capital**
rows.administration:
**Administrator** (Art 239)
Usually a serving IAS officer
Reports to Union Home Ministry
**Direct Central rule**
Also acts as Governor-like figure
rows.legislature:
**No Legislature**
**No Assembly, No CM**
Direct Central administration
**Municipal Corporation** for local governance
**1 Lok Sabha seat**
rows.special_provisions:
**Capital of 2 States**: Punjab & Haryana (Art 239)
**Punjab Reorganisation Act 1966**: Created Chandigarh as UT
**Pending transfer to Punjab** (under Punjab Reorganisation Act)
**Haryana claims**: Compensation in return
**Stalemate continues** since 1966
rows.key_bills_acts:
**Punjab Reorganisation Act 1966**:
• Created Chandigarh as UT
• Made it capital of both Punjab & Haryana
• Provision for transfer to Punjab after Hindi-speaking areas of Punjab given to Haryana
• **Transfer never happened** (political reasons)

**Rajiv-Longowal Accord 1985**: Promised transfer to Punjab
• **Not implemented** due to opposition from Haryana

**Current status**: Indefinite UT status
rows.exam_points:
• **Only UT** that is **capital of 2 States** (Punjab + Haryana)
• Created by **Punjab Reorganisation Act 1966**
• **Planned city** (designed by Le Corbusier - French architect)
• **Pending transfer** to Punjab since 1966 (never happened)
• **1 Lok Sabha seat** (Chandigarh constituency)
• No Legislature despite being inhabited UT
• **High Court**: Common for Punjab, Haryana & Chandigarh
• **Municipal Corporation** for local governance
• **Political deadlock**: Punjab wants it, Haryana opposes

rows.key_bills_acts:
**Andaman & Nicobar Islands (Protection of Aboriginal Tribes) Regulation 1956**:
• Protection of tribal areas
• Restricted entry to tribal zones
• Special permissions required

**Key Islands**:
• **North Sentinel Island**: Home to Sentinelese tribe (most isolated tribe - no contact policy)
• **Port Blair**: Capital

**Strategic**: **Tri-Services Command** headquarters (only joint command in India)
rows.exam_points:
• **1 Lok Sabha seat** (Andaman & Nicobar Islands)
• **Southernmost point of India**: Indira Point (Great Nicobar)
• **Only Tri-Services Command** in India (HQ: Port Blair)
• **Cellular Jail** (Kala Pani) - National Memorial
• **North Sentinel Island**: Most isolated tribe (no contact policy)

• **2004 Tsunami**: Severely affected

• **Only Muslim-majority UT** (96%+ Muslim)
• **1 Lok Sabha seat** (smallest constituency by population)

• **Coral islands** (only coral islands in India)

• **2021 reforms controversy**: Liquor, land acquisition - local opposition
• **Arabian Sea**: West of Kerala coast

rows.special_provisions:
**Merged UT**: Two separate UTs merged in 2020
**Geographically non-contiguous**: DNH surrounded by Gujarat & Maharashtra; DD in Gujarat coast
**Former Portuguese colonies** (liberated 1954-1961)
**Unique status**: One UT, two separate regions

rows.key_bills_acts:
**Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu (Merger of Union Territories) Act 2019**:
• Merged two UTs into one
• Effective: Jan 26, 2020
• **Reasons**: Better administration, reduced expenditure
• Single Administrator for both regions

**Historical**:
• **Portuguese rule**: Till 1954 (DNH) & 1961 (DD)
• DNH liberated by locals in 1954
• DD liberated in Operation Vijay 1961 (with Goa)
• Made separate UTs in 1961
rows.exam_points:
• **Merged UT** (effective Jan 26, 2020) - Latest merger
• **Former Portuguese colonies** (like Goa)
• **Geographically separated**: DNH inland, DD on coast
• **2 Lok Sabha seats** (DNH 1 + DD 1) - Unique among merged UTs
• **DNH**: Surrounded by Gujarat & Maharashtra
• **DD**: 2 districts - Daman + Diu (separated by Gulf of Khambhat)
• **Capital**: Daman
• **Industrial hub**: Many factories, SEZs
• **Tourism**: Beaches, Portuguese architecture
• Only UT formed by **merging 2 existing UTs**

data.summary: India has **8 Union Territories** (Art 239): Delhi (NCT), Puducherry, J&K, Ladakh, Chandigarh, Andaman & Nicobar, Lakshadweep, DNH & DD. **3 UTs with Legislature**: Delhi (Art 239AA - 70 members), Puducherry (Art 239A - 33 members), J&K (114 members). **5 UTs without Legislature**: Ladakh, Chandigarh, A&N Islands, Lakshadweep, DNH & DD. **Delhi**: Most controversial (Art 239AA; 2021 Act strengthened LG; 2023 SC verdict on Services). **J&K**: Only State downgraded to UT (2019); Art 370 abrogated; most important for exams. **Ladakh**: Newest UT (2019); no Legislature; demands 6th Schedule. **Chandigarh**: Capital of Punjab + Haryana; transfer to Punjab pending since 1966. **Puducherry**: 3 nominated MLAs; former French colony. **Lakshadweep**: Smallest UT (32 sq km); only Muslim-majority UT. **DNH & DD**: Merged UT (2020); geographically separated; former Portuguese. All UTs administered by LG/Administrator appointed by President. Parliament legislates for UTs. Exam focus: Delhi (Art 239AA, 2021 Act), J&K (Art 370 abrogation, Reorganisation Act 2019), constitutional provisions (Art 239, 239A, 239AA).

additionalInfo.title: Key Constitutional Provisions & Common Features

comparison.detail: Every UT shall be administered by President through Administrator/LG appointed by him. President can specify designation.
Puducherry can have Legislature & Council of Ministers. President may create such provisions by regulation.
Special status for Delhi. Legislature can make laws on State List & Concurrent List (except Police, Public Order, Land - Entry 1, 2, 18).
Delhi shall have Council of Ministers with CM. Council collectively responsible to Assembly. Max 10% of Assembly strength.
Parliament can make laws for UTs. President can make regulations for UTs (except Delhi, Puducherry, J&K).
Parliament can create/extend jurisdiction of HCs to UTs. Delhi HC (Delhi), Calcutta HC (A&N), Kerala HC (Lakshadweep), Bombay HC (DNH & DD).
All UTs have representation in Lok Sabha. Total 20 seats reserved for UTs (Delhi 7, A&N 1, Puducherry 1, Lakshadweep 1, Chandigarh 1, DNH 1, DD 1, Ladakh 1, J&K 5).
Only 3 UTs have RS representation: Delhi (3), Puducherry (1), J&K (4). Total 8 RS seats for UTs.

additionalInfo.examTip: **Most Important for Exams**: Delhi (Art 239AA, 2021 Amendment Act, LG vs CM power), J&K (Art 370 abrogation, Reorganisation Act 2019, downgrade from State), constitutional articles (Art 239, 239A, 239AA, 239AB, 240, 241), and differences between UTs with/without Legislature. Know which UTs have Legislature (only 3: Delhi, Puducherry, J&K) and special provisions for each.
